title: Big Hole Pass
text:
Big Hole Pass (elevation: ) is a high <a href="mountain%20pass">mountain pass</a> on the <a href="Montana">Montana</a>–<a href="Idaho">Idaho</a> border approximately due south of Montana State Highway 43 in the <a href="Beaverhead%E2%80%93Deerlodge%20National%20Forest">Beaverhead–Deerlodge National Forest</a> in <a href="Beaverhead%20County%2C%20Montana">Beaverhead County, Montana</a>, and <a href="Salmon%E2%80%93Challis%20National%20Forest">Salmon National Forest</a> in <a href="Lemhi%20County%2C%20Idaho">Lemhi County, Idaho</a>. This location should not be confused with a sign on Montana Highway 278 at the height of land west of <a href="Dillon%2C%20Montana">Dillon, Montana</a>, that denotes the eastern entrance to the Big Hole valley.
The <a href="Continental%20Divide%20Trail">Continental Divide Trail</a> goes over this pass, which is about south-southeast of the more famous <a href="Chief%20Joseph%20Pass">Chief Joseph Pass</a>. The pass can be approached on a <a href="Forest%20service%20road">Forest Service road</a>, Dahlonega Creek Road (079), from the west or Forest Service Road #943 from Highway 43 from the east.
On their return trip the <a href="Lewis%20and%20Clark%20Expedition">Lewis and Clark Expedition</a>
separated at <a href="Traveler%27s%20Rest%20%28Lolo%2C%20Montana%29">Traveler's Rest</a> in modern-day Montana. On July 3, 1806, <a href="Meriwether%20Lewis">Meriwether Lewis</a> headed north to explore the <a href="Marias%20River">Marias River</a>, while <a href="William%20Clark%20%28explorer%29">William Clark</a> headed up the <a href="Bitterroot%20River">Bitterroot River</a> with 50 men, <a href="Sacagawea">Sacagawea</a> and her baby. They crossed Big Hole Pass on their way to their cache of supplies at <a href="Camp%20Fortunate">Camp Fortunate</a>.
Recreation.
This pass cannot be seen from a paved highway but is frequently traversed by through-hikers on the <a href="Continental%20Divide%20Trail">Continental Divide Trail</a> (CDT). Hunters, fishermen and other outdoors people use the area. Within a mile of Big Hole Pass, a woods road sits on the actual Continental Divide. Water draining from the muddy road on the left goes toward the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific Ocean</a>, while water on the right goes toward the <a href="Atlantic%20Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a>.
